articles.title: Bun 1.0: Is It a Toolkit? Is It a Runtime? It's Both
articles.description: You’ve used Node, you’ve seen Deno, now Bun has grown up too. It’s a performance-oriented server-side JS runtime built atop JavaScriptCore and makes the unique claim of being “a drop-in replacement for Node.js.” It includes extras like transpilation, bundling, package management, and a Jest-compatible test runner too. The post goes into a lot of depth, but we enjoyed the Bun team’s ▶️ 10 minute introductory video. Does Bun deliver on all its promises yet? No. Is it promising? Yes.
articles.author: Jarred Sumner et al.

articles.title: Why Does every() Return true for Empty Arrays?
articles.description: Nicholas wondered how a condition can possibly be satisfied when there aren’t any values to test, so he dug into the language specs to understand the logic.
articles.author: Nicholas C. Zakas

articles.title: A First Look at TypeScript 5.3
articles.description: TypeScript 5.2 landed a few weeks ago, which means TypeScript 5.3 is already in the works (the final release is due in November), with possible features to think about including Import Attributes, throw expressions, and isolated declarations.
articles.author: Matt Pocock

articles.title: JavaScript's New Array Grouping Methods
articles.description: A look at Object.groupBy and Map.groupBy. The proposal including these methods is currently at stage 3 at TC39, but initial support is creeping into dev builds of browsers.
articles.author: Phil Nash

articles.title: JPEG and EXIF Data Manipulation in JavaScript
articles.description: A look at how to pick through the JPEG format and read and replace EXIF tags directly without leaning on a third party library.
articles.author: Cédric Patchane

articles.title: ▶  Building a Mario Game Complete with Auth and Score Saving
articles.description: Ania tackles the implementation of a game in her usual thorough, step-by-step manner.
articles.author: Ania Kubów

articles.title: Running a Playwright Script on AWS Lambda
articles.description: If you’ve struggled to make it work too, Matt has some pointers.
articles.author: Matt Steele

articles.title: A New Method to Validate URLs
articles.description: URL.canParse isn’t broadly supported yet, but can be easily polyfilled.
articles.author: Stefan Judis

articles.title: How to Run a GitHub Gist with npx
articles.description: This is an interesting way to quickly deploy a script.
articles.author: Kelly Fox

articles.title: Shadcn for Vue: Components You Can Copy and Paste
articles.description: A community-led Vue port of the React-oriented shadcn/ui, a suite of attractive components built with Tailwind CSS and Radix UI, thus making them easy to ‘copy and paste’ into your own apps.
articles.author: Radix Vue Project

articles.title: npm-check-updates: Update package.json Dependencies to Latest Versions
articles.description: That is, as opposed to the specified versions. It include a handy -i interactive mode so you can look at potential upgrades and then opt in to them one by one.
articles.author: Raine Revere

articles.title: Starry Night 3.0: GitHub-Like Syntax Highlighting
articles.description: GitHub’s own syntax highlighter isn’t open source, but Starry Night uses WebAssembly (to get access to the Oniguruma regex engine) to get as close as it can.
articles.author: Titus Wormer

articles.title: Vuestic 1.8: Open Source UI Library for Vue 3
articles.description: A library of more than 60 customizable components. v1.8 introduces new Layout and Textarea components. Official homepage.
articles.author: Epicmax

articles.title: Goxygen 0.7: Quickly Generate a Go Backend for a JS Project
articles.description: A tool that sets up a new Go-based project with Angular, React, or Vue in the front-end, and Docker and Docker Compose files to make it all work.
articles.author: Sasha Shpota

articles.title: xterm.js 5.3.0: Build Terminals in the Browser
articles.description: It’s used in many projects like VS Code, cPanel, Azure Cloud Shell, and other browser-based IDEs. There’s a live demo on the homepage to try.
articles.author: xterm.js team

articles.title: Transformers.js: State-of-the-Art Machine Learning for the Web
articles.description: A JavaScript library designed to be functionally equivalent to Hugging Face’s transformers Python library meaning you can run the same pretrained models using a very similar API. You can do things like ML-powered speech recognition directly in your browser using OpenAI’s Whisper model. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Joshua Lochner et al.

articles.title: Microsoft TypeChat: An Approach for Type-Safe LLM Responses
articles.description: Anders Hejlsberg and Daniel Rosenwasser of TypeScript fame are just two of the prominent names attached to this project, demonstrating the huge interest within MS for LLMs. TypeChat’s goal is to work around the issue of LLMs outputting unstructured natural language and to direct output into a typed form.
articles.author: Hejlsberg, Lucco, Rosenwasser et al.

articles.title: WebLLM: Run LLM Models in the Browser with WebGPU
articles.description: Less directly JavaScript, as it uses WebGPU, but yet another way to run large language models directly within the browser and that you can control from JavaScript. GitHub repo.
articles.author: MLC LLM

articles.title: TensorFlow.js: Machine Learning for JavaScript Developers
articles.description: Slightly lower level, but a great way to train and deploy models in the browser or in Node.js. There are, of course, lots of demos, too.
articles.author: TensorFlow

articles.description: 📅 ViteConf is taking place this October 5-6. It's free and online.

The August 2023 build of VS Code has just been released and includes improvements to the JS debugger including WebAssembly module decompilation, as well as Move to File and Inline Variable refactorings.
Linus Groh is working on a JavaScript engine in Zig called Kiesel, mostly as a learning project, but it's passing 25% of test262 after four months of effort.
While searching for something else, I encountered this JavaScript tutorial from 1996 that's still online. Amazingly, most of it still works fine today.
Esteemed Microsoft code archaeologist Raymond Chen looks at how freestanding JS functions using this can be mistaken for a constructor by VS Code’s static analyzer.
MikroORM 5.8 – Powerful Node.js ORM.
Reason 3.10 – Write code in OCaml, but for the JS ecosystem.
Happy DOM 11.0 – A JS implementation of a web browser sans UI.
Node.js v20.6.1 (Current)

articles.title: Stop Lazy Loading Product and Hero Images
articles.description: Jason highlights a performance issue seen on many ecommerce sites around lazy loading usage, particularly its overuse: “Lazy loading is a key technique when it comes to increasing page performance, but like any technique, it shouldn’t be applied everywhere”.
articles.author: Jason Grigsby

articles.title: W3C Introduces Web Sustainability Guidelines
articles.description: From the Sustainable Web Design Community Group comes a set of guidelines on Sustainable Web Design, explaining how to design and build “digital products and services that put people and the planet first”. You can read the draft here.
articles.author: W3C

articles.title: Web Components Accessibility FAQ
articles.description: Manuel runs through the most important questions regarding web component accessibility, including dependencies, shadow DOM queries, custom elements, and more.
articles.author: Manuel Matuzović

articles.title: 💛  Memories of Molly
articles.description: Last week we shared the sad news that Molly Holzschlag passed away, here Eric Meyer reflects on her memory. Others in the web community have also shared their thoughts on Molly, including words from Jay Hoffmann, Bruce Lawson, Aaron Gustafson, and Deborah Edwards-Oñoro.
articles.author: Eric Meyer

articles.title: How to Make Charts and Graphs More Accessible
articles.description: Some solid pointers on how to make your visual data accessible and more usable.
articles.author: Whitney Lewis

articles.title: Creating Custom Easing Effects in CSS Animations with linear()
articles.description: This CSS timing function enables custom easing in animations. Here’s a look at how it works compared with other timing functions used for easing, along with practical examples.
articles.author: Michelle Barker

articles.title: The New Google Fonts: Finding What You’re Looking for
articles.description: The Google Fonts website has had a redesign, with new search and filter options.
articles.author: Tobias Kunisch (Google)

articles.title: Scroll-Driven Animations Debugger: A DevTools Extension
articles.description: A new Chrome DevTools extension specifically to visualize and debug scroll-driven animations.
articles.author: Bramus Van Damme

articles.title: unpic/placeholder: A Library for Generating Pure CSS Image Placeholders
articles.description: This is done by extracting the dominant color from an image or by server-side rendering a BlurHash value, which then is used to display a temporary image during load time.
articles.author: Matt Kane

articles.title: qr-code: Web Component for Animatable SVG-Based QR Codes
articles.description: We’re not entirely sure why you’d want to animate a QR code, but the effects are pretty neat. You can try out the demo here.
articles.author: Jason Dreyzehner

articles.title: CSS Loaders: A Collection of 500+ Loading Animations
articles.description: This is a huge collection of animated single-element CSS-only loaders. You’re bound to find one that suits your project here.
articles.author: Temani Afif

articles.title: BlendIcons: 140K+ Free Icons in Various Categories and Styles
articles.description: A simple UI lets you search via keyword and you can filter by icon styles (bold, filled, etc.). Each icon is available in different formats including SVG, PNG, JSX, CSS, HTML, Base64, etc.
articles.author: Blendicons

articles.title: Crop Video: Online Tool to Quickly Crop a Video File
articles.description: From Adobe Express, this tool gives you pre-built crop settings for landscape, portrait  (i.e. for TikTok), square, or just do it freeform.
articles.author: Adobe Express

articles.title: React Plock: A 1KB Masonry Grid Component
articles.description: TypeScript-ready and it’s easy to customize the grid columns and rows for responsive layouts in the style of Unsplash, say.
articles.author: Renato Pozzi

articles.title: Run Lighthouse on PageSpeed Insights Against a Set of URLs
articles.description: You'll need Node.js, but this will let you see which of the sites you supply is fastest. In other words, something like “Amazing Race” for websites?
articles.author: Zach Leatherman

articles.description: What were the "no-no's" of web design in 1999? Jakob Nielsen shared what he deemed the top ten mistakes you could make from a usability perspective. Helpful insights that still mostly stand up today.
WOFF may have left the building as a web font format, but long live WOFF2!
WordPress has an interesting new 100-year plan to help you secure your 'online legacy for a lifetime'. It's not cheap.
Chrome is getting a bit of a new look based on Google's 'Material You' design language.
Version 15 of developer browser Polypane is out, running on Chromium 116, with a new browser panel, performance improvements, and more.
